notifications.body: Design systems have exploded in the business software community in recent years. Back in 2018 the Enterprise UX Industry Report 2017/ 2018 indicated that 69% of enterprise user experience (UX) teams had adopted one.  Today, this camp includes many household (and boardroom) names, including Shopify, Google, Uber, IBM, Adobe and Atlassian. A key factor driving the popularity of design systems (and the increased overall investment in UX) is pressure from industry upstarts (Uber, Shopify, AirBnb) that have forced incumbents to adapt to a new breed of consumer: digital natives, who are flooded with choices, accustomed to self-onboarding on intuitively designed apps, and take excellent UX as a given.
notifications.title: The business case for adopting a design system

notifications.body: We have updated our subscription tier pricing and features in order to simplify our subscriptions and make Prime affordable to more members of our community.
notifications.title: Prime subscription price lowered, component factory components open sourced

notifications.body: Tech giants Microsoft and Google are pushing progressive web applications (PWAs) as the standard for their app stores. They have independently, and through joint effort, found ways to turn existing web apps into PWAs, and to wrap them to be supported on different platforms. These technologies have been combined into one code-free tool: Meet PWABuilder.
notifications.title: PWABuilder and Vaadin

notifications.body: Design systems become more important as applications grow in complexity and in number. Scalable, reusable and modular code, along with compatible visual assets, are key when organizations build multiple apps for different purposes, but still wish to maintain a level of consistency throughout their UIs.
notifications.title: Design systems and standards-based Web Components

notifications.body:
We received a lot of feedback from our community regarding the TypeScript view support we added in Vaadin 15. Many of you were excited about the new capabilities it offers for Vaadin apps. But, there was also some confusion about this change. In particular, many in our community asked: "How does TypeScript support (and client-side views) fit into the bigger Vaadin picture?”

Today, we're introducing two new names —Vaadin Flow and Vaadin Fusion—to clarify the different ways in which you can build a Vaadin application.
notifications.title: (Re)introducing Vaadin Flow and Fusion

notifications.body: Last Thursday saw the unveiling of our initial release of Vaadin’s new collaboration feature, which allows developers to rapidly build real-time form editing features directly into Vaadin applications, with only a few lines of code.
notifications.title: A sneak-peek at the future of Vaadin’s real-time collaboration features
